importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: This is the year when Nicholas Rossi allegedly raped two women in northern Utah, with one incident occurring after a personal ad on Craigslist, and the other involving a theft-related visit to his apartment in Orem.
Utah authorities identified Rossi through a decade-old DNA rape kit in 2018, leading to renewed investigation and eventual arrest after a fabricated obituary claimed his death.
An online obituary falsely claimed Rossi died of non-Hodgkin lymphoma in February 2020, which authorities and family members disputed, indicating he may have faked his death to evade justice.
Rossi was extradited to Utah in January 2024 after being arrested in Scotland while receiving treatment for COVID-19, following recognition of his tattoos from an Interpol notice.
The sentencing date for Nicholas Rossi occurred on Monday, October 20, 2025, marking the culmination of legal proceedings following two rape convictions.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The decade-long period from 2008 to 2018 spans the timeline of the crimes committed, the DNA kit backlog investigation, and the eventual identification and arrest of Rossi.
This period covers the time between Rossi’s alleged death (2020), his flight to Scotland, and his eventual extradition to Utah, highlighting efforts to track and apprehend a fugitive sex offender.

keyTakeAways: Nicholas Rossi, a 38-year-old man from Rhode Island, was convicted of raping two women in northern Utah in 2008 and is now serving a prison sentence ranging from five years to life.

Rossi allegedly faked his death in 2020 by claiming to have died of non-Hodgkin lymphoma, which led to him fleeing the U.S. and living in Scotland, where he was arrested in 2024 after hospital staff recognized his tattoos.
The case involved a decade-long DNA backlog in Utah’s rape kit system, which enabled authorities to re-identify Rossi through genetic data.
Rossi used multiple aliases, including Arthur Knight, and maintained his innocence during trial and sentencing, claiming the victims were lying.
The victim described the trauma of the assault and the lasting emotional damage, emphasizing the need for accountability and safety.
Utah law allows prison sentences to be given as a range (five years to life) for first-degree rape, with a parole board determining release eligibility.
Rossi’s history includes prior sex offenses, failure to register as a sex offender in Rhode Island, and fraud charges in Ohio.
The case illustrates the dangers of a flight risk and the importance of DNA evidence in solving cold cases.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Nicholas Rossi, a 38-year-old man from Rhode Island, was convicted in two separate cases of raping two women in northern Utah in 2008. After being identified through a decade-old DNA rape kit in 2018, Rossi allegedly faked his death in 2020 by claiming to have died of non-Hodgkin lymphoma, prompting him to flee the U.S. and live in Scotland. He was arrested in Scotland in 2024 when hospital staff recognized tattoos linked to Brown University, which were part of an Interpol notice. After a protracted legal battle, he was extradited to Utah and sentenced to a range of five years to life in prison under Utah law. The case underscores the dangers of flight risks and the power of DNA evidence in solving cold cases. The victim described the trauma of the assault, emphasizing the need for accountability, safety, and justice.
title: Man accused of faking his own death and fleeing the US after rape charges gets at least five years in prison
